sections.title: Local Self-Government-Urban
sections.content_md: An **urban area** is regarded as one which is a town or a city, has a minimum population of 5000, and at least 75 per cent of its population is engaged in non-agricultural pursuits. A **town** is generally a smaller urban area, while large towns are called **cities**. According to the Census Commission, cities with a population of more than 40 lakh are known as **metropolitan cities**. The local self-government institutions in these areas function independently of one another.

sections.title: Urban: Municipal Committees and Municipal Corporations-meaning and functions.
sections.content_md: **Municipal Committees** and **Municipal Corporations** are the primary institutions of local self-government in urban areas. Municipal Committees, also known as Municipal Councils, are established for smaller urban areas, while Municipal Corporations are set up for larger urban areas like cities. Their primary meaning and function is to provide local administration, civic amenities, and public services to the residents of the designated urban area, functioning as democratic units of self-governance.

sections.title: THE CONSTITUTION (74TH AMENDMENT) ACT, 1992
sections.content_md: In many States, local bodies had become weak and ineffective due to reasons like the failure to hold regular elections. To make urban local bodies more effective and vibrant democratic units, the **Constitution (74th Amendment) Act, 1992**, also known as the **Nagarpalika and Municipalities Act**, was passed.

sections.title: The salient features of the Act are the following:
sections.content_md: The Constitution (74th Amendment) Act, 1992 introduced several key features to strengthen urban local governance.

sections.title: The Act gives constitutional status to urban local bodies.
sections.content_md: The Act provides a constitutional foundation for urban local bodies, ensuring their place within the country's governance framework.

sections.title: The Act provides for direct election to all the local self-government bodies.
sections.content_md: This provision ensures that representatives in urban local bodies are directly elected by the people, strengthening democratic principles at the local level.

sections.title: A fixed tenure of five years for the municipalities has been prescribed.
sections.content_md: The Act mandates a uniform and fixed term of five years for all municipalities, providing stability and predictability to their functioning.

sections.title: 33 per cent of the seats should be reserved for women under each category of SC/ST/Backward Classes.
sections.content_md: To promote women's participation in local governance, the Act reserves one-third of the seats for women, including seats reserved for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Backward Classes.

sections.title: District Planning Committee to be constituted by the State Government.
sections.content_md: The Act provides for the establishment of a **District Planning Committee** by the State Government to consolidate the plans prepared by Panchayats and Municipalities in the district.

sections.title: The Act provides for three tier local bodies for urban areas as under:
sections.content_md: The 74th Amendment Act established a three-tier structure for urban local self-government based on the size of the urban area.

sections.title: Municipal Corporations for larger urban areas.
sections.content_md: **Municipal Corporations** are constituted for larger urban areas, such as major cities.

sections.title: Municipal Councils for smaller urban areas.
sections.content_md: **Municipal Councils** (also known as Municipalities or Municipal Boards) are set up for smaller urban areas or towns.

sections.title: Nagar Panchayats for areas in transition from a rural area to urban area.
sections.content_md: **Nagar Panchayats** are established for areas that are in a transitional phase from being rural to becoming urban.

sections.title: In addition, there are Town Area Committees, Cantonment Boards and Port Trusts in certain urban areas.
sections.content_md: Besides the three-tier structure, other forms of urban local bodies exist in specific areas, such as **Town Area Committees**, **Cantonment Boards** (for civilian populations in military areas), and **Port Trusts** (for port areas).

sections.title: MUNICIPAL CORPORATION
sections.content_md: The Municipal Corporation carries out its functions through well-organised divisions or departments such as the Water Supply and Sewage Disposal Undertaking, Housing Board, Education Department, and Electricity Department. These are managed by experienced and qualified professionals.

sections.title: Municipal Corporation is a local self-government unit in big cities.
sections.content_md: A **Municipal Corporation** is the local self-governing body responsible for the administration of large urban areas or big cities.

sections.title: ELECTION
sections.content_md: The members of the Corporation are elected in the same way as members of the Legislative Assembly. The municipal areas are divided into **Wards** instead of constituencies. Elections are held on the basis of **Universal Adult Franchise** through a secret ballot. The number of representatives is determined by the population of the city.

sections.title: TERM
sections.content_md: A fixed tenure of **five years** has been provided by the Constitution (74th Amendment) Act, 1992. A Corporation can be dissolved before its term ends by the Governor of the State on the advice of the Council of Ministers. However, elections for a new Corporation must be completed before the expiry of the current term. In case of dissolution, elections must be held within six months.

sections.title: COMPOSITION
sections.content_md:
A Municipal Corporation comprises the following:
(a) General Council
(b) The Mayor
(c) The Standing Committees
(d) A Municipal Commissioner

sections.title: General Council
sections.content_md: The **General Council** is composed of elected members known as **Municipal Councillors**. They are elected directly by the people on the basis of Universal Adult Franchise. The number of seats depends on the city's population and is determined by the State government. There are reserved constituencies for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. The General Council also co-opts some members known as **Aldermen**, who are eminent persons of the city nominated by the Governor.

sections.title: The Mayor
sections.content_md: The Councillors, along with the Aldermen, elect the **Mayor** and the **Deputy Mayor** from amongst themselves. They are generally elected for a period of one year but can be re-elected annually for the full five-year term of the Corporation.

sections.title: The Standing Committees
sections.content_md: Members of the General Council are represented on **Standing Committees** through elections. Different Standing Committees are formed to deal with specific subjects like finance, health, engineering, taxation, and welfare schemes.

sections.title: A Municipal Commissioner
sections.content_md: The **Municipal Commissioner** is appointed by the Governor, usually for a term of 5 years. In the case of a Union Territory, the appointment is made by the Central Government. He/She is the Chief Executive of the Corporation.

sections.title: The Municipal Corporation of Delhi
sections.content_md: The Municipal Corporation of Delhi had its first formal meeting on June 1, 1863. It came into being in February 1863 as a constituent committee to frame by-laws for the city. The year also saw the first sanitation and conservancy system, a Unani dispensary in Sadar Bazar, and the registration of births and deaths. The following year introduced a fire fighting system, water supply, and taxation. The Municipal Corporation of Delhi, as set up by an Act of Parliament in 1958, is the second largest municipal body in the world.

sections.title: Functions of the Mayor
sections.content_md: The Mayor performs several important functions as the head of the Municipal Corporation.

sections.title: Considered as the 'First Citizen', he/she represents the city at various ceremonies and receives foreign guests coming to visit the city. This is considered his most important duty.
sections.content_md: The Mayor is considered the **'First Citizen'** of the city. A primary duty is to represent the city at official ceremonies and receive foreign dignitaries.

sections.title: He/She presides over the meetings of the Corporation.
sections.content_md: The Mayor is the presiding officer for all meetings of the Municipal Corporation's General Council.

sections.title: He/She regulates and conducts business of the Corporation.
sections.content_md: The Mayor is responsible for regulating and conducting the business and proceedings of the Corporation's meetings.

sections.title: He/She fixes the agenda for consideration at the meetings of the Corporation.
sections.content_md: The Mayor sets the agenda for the meetings of the Corporation, determining which matters will be discussed.

sections.title: He/She obtains reports from the Municipal Commissioner regarding various projects and programmes undertaken by the Corporation.
sections.content_md: The Mayor has the authority to seek and obtain reports from the Municipal Commissioner about the various projects and programs being implemented by the Corporation.

sections.title: He/She acts as a link between the Corporation and the State government.
sections.content_md: The Mayor serves as a crucial communication link between the Municipal Corporation and the State government.

sections.title: Standing Committees:
sections.content_md: The members of the General Council are represented on **Standing Committees** through elections. There are different Standing Committees to deal with subjects like finance, health, engineering, taxation and welfare schemes.

sections.title: Municipal Commissioner:
sections.content_md: The **Municipal Commissioner** is appointed by the Governor, usually for a term of 5 years. In a Union Territory, the appointment is made by the Central Government. He/She is the **Chief Executive** of the Corporation.

sections.title: To carry on and control the administration of the Corporation.
sections.content_md: The Municipal Commissioner is responsible for carrying on and controlling the day-to-day administration of the Corporation.

sections.title: To implement the projects and programmes as laid down by the General Council.
sections.content_md: He/She ensures the implementation of all projects and programmes that have been approved by the General Council.

sections.title: To maintain and safeguard all municipal properties, records etc.
sections.content_md: The Commissioner is tasked with the maintenance and safeguarding of all properties, records, and assets belonging to the municipality.

sections.title: To prepare financial budgets and perform other related functions.
sections.content_md: A key function is the preparation of the annual financial budget for the Corporation and performing other related financial duties.

sections.title: To take part in the meetings of the Council but he cannot move any resolution or vote in the meetings. He also keeps records of the minutes and proceedings of the meetings.
sections.content_md: The Municipal Commissioner participates in the meetings of the Council but does not have the right to move a resolution or to vote. He/She is also responsible for recording the minutes and proceedings of the meetings.

sections.title: FUNCTIONS OF THE MUNICIPAL CORPORATION
sections.content_md: The Municipal Corporation is the local self-government unit of the city, dealing with matters concerning its residents. Its functions are generally divided into two categories: obligatory (compulsory) and discretionary (optional).

sections.title: Compulsory Functions:
sections.content_md: These are the essential functions that a Municipal Corporation is obligated to perform.

sections.title: Provision of electricity, water, sewage disposal. These functions are carried through various departments which have the services of experts and engineers who are appointed as full time employees of the Corporation.
sections.content_md: **Public Utilities:** Provision of essential services like electricity, clean drinking water, and sewage disposal. These are managed by specialized departments with full-time expert staff and engineers.

sections.title: Provision of public health services like provision of hospitals, dispensaries, family welfare centres. It has to organise and carry on special public health measures to prevent spread of communicable diseases. Removal and disposal of garbage, dealing with other city wastes are priority functions. The Corporation appoints its own staff to carry on these functions.
sections.content_md: **Public Health Services:** Includes establishing and maintaining hospitals, dispensaries, and family welfare centres. It involves measures to prevent the spread of communicable diseases and prioritizing the removal and disposal of garbage and other city wastes.

sections.title: Provision of public conveniences and utilities like roads, buildings, bus-shelters, demolition of dangerous structures, plantation of trees, provision of public urinals and toilets.
sections.content_md: **Public Conveniences:** Involves the construction and maintenance of public infrastructure such as roads, buildings, bus shelters, public urinals, and toilets. It also includes demolishing unsafe structures and planting trees.

sections.title: Provision of educational institutions like primary and secondary schools including organisation of adult literacy classes, organising and undertaking promotion of sports and games and providing necessary facilities.
sections.content_md: **Education and Recreation:** Establishing and running primary and secondary schools, organising adult literacy classes, and promoting sports and games by providing the necessary facilities.

sections.title: Maintenance of records of births and deaths and maintenance and upkeep of cremation and burial grounds.
sections.content_md: **Record Keeping:** Maintaining a systematic record of all births and deaths within the city limits, and managing the upkeep of cremation and burial grounds.

sections.title: Undertaking of public safety and security like maintenance of fire department together with fire engines; disaster like floods and earthquake management groups etc.
sections.content_md: **Public Safety and Security:** Ensuring public safety by maintaining a fire department with fire engines and establishing management groups for disasters like floods and earthquakes.

sections.title: Preparation, publishing and issuing of annual report of the Corporation stating its various activities, projects and programmes
sections.content_md: **Reporting:** Preparing, publishing, and issuing an annual report that details the Corporation's activities, projects, and programmes for the year.

sections.title: Discretionary or Optional Functions:
sections.content_md: These are non-essential functions that a Municipal Corporation may undertake depending on the availability of funds.

sections.title: Public housing through housing boards.
sections.content_md: Providing **public housing** for residents, often implemented through dedicated housing boards.

sections.title: Construction and maintenance of public parks, libraries, museums, theatre, akharas, picnic resorts etc.
sections.content_md: Building and maintaining **public recreational spaces** such as parks, libraries, museums, theatres, 'akharas' (traditional gyms), and picnic resorts.

sections.title: Establishing and maintaining children's homes, orphanages, old-age homes, night shelters and rest houses.
sections.content_md: Setting up and managing **social welfare institutions** like children's homes, orphanages, old-age homes, night shelters, and rest houses.

sections.title: Undertaking welfare schemes, organising fares, functions, melas.
sections.content_md: Implementing various **welfare schemes** and organising public events like fairs, functions, and 'melas'.

sections.title: Beautification of city.
sections.content_md: Undertaking projects for the **beautification of the city**, such as landscaping, installing fountains, and maintaining public art.

sections.title: MUNICIPAL COMMITTEE
sections.content_md: The Governor of a state determines the areas for different forms of urban bodies based on factors like the population of the area, density of population, revenue generated by the local body, and the percentage of employment in non-agricultural activities.

sections.title: Municipal Councils and Municipal Corporations are constituted in smaller urban areas and larger urban areas respectively.
sections.content_md: **Municipal Councils** are constituted in smaller urban areas, whereas **Municipal Corporations** are constituted in larger urban areas.

sections.title: A Municipal Committee is set up for smaller towns.
sections.content_md: A **Municipal Committee** is set up for smaller towns. These bodies are also called **Municipal Boards** or **Municipalities**. Their organisation is similar to that of a Municipal Corporation but is smaller in scale. It generally has three wings: the General Body, the Chairman/President, and the Chief Executive Officer.

sections.title: General Body of the Municipal Committee:
sections.content_md: The members of the General Body of the Municipal Committee are called **Councillors**. They are elected from **Municipal wards**, and the number of members depends on the population of the city.

sections.title: Eligibility: Eligibility for contesting elections to the General Body of the Municipal Committee are same as in the case of Municipal Corporation.
sections.content_md: The eligibility criteria for contesting elections to the General Body of a Municipal Committee are the same as those for a Municipal Corporation.

sections.title: Term: According to the new Nagarpalika Act, all rural and urban local self-government bodies have a uniform term of 5 years in all states.
sections.content_md: As per the **Nagarpalika Act**, all urban local self-government bodies, including Municipal Committees, have a uniform term of **5 years** across all states.

sections.title: Chairman/President:
sections.content_md: A **Chairperson** and a **Vice-Chairperson** are elected indirectly by the members from among themselves. The Chairperson of a Municipality has vast powers, and their functions are similar to those of the Mayor of a Municipal Corporation.

sections.title: Chief Executive Officer:
sections.content_md: The **Chief Executive Officer** is an appointee of the State government and usually belongs to the State Civil Services. This officer is responsible for the administrative wing of the Municipal Committee.

sections.title: Other Office Bearers:
sections.content_md: Similar to a Municipal Corporation, a Municipal Committee has various departments like Education, Health, Engineering, Taxation, etc. These departments are managed by senior officers, engineers, or other experts.

sections.title: THE DISTRICT ADMINISTRATION
sections.content_md: The local government in an area functions at the district level under the overall charge of a **District Collector** or **Deputy Commissioner**. This officer often combines both roles and is also the highest officer in a district for revenue collection. The Deputy Commissioner belongs to the **Indian Administrative Service (IAS)** and is appointed by the State government. Other government officers who work under the Deputy Commissioner include the Tehsildar, Naib Tehsildars, Kanungos, and Lekhpal or Patwari. At the district level, law and order is managed by the Superintendent of Police.

sections.title: Functions:
sections.content_md: The Deputy Commissioner is the chief executive officer of the district and performs almost every function of local government.

sections.title: Collection of Revenue.
sections.content_md: The Deputy Commissioner is responsible for the collection of land revenue and other government taxes in the district.

sections.title: Maintenance and Updating of land record.
sections.content_md: Ensuring the proper maintenance and regular updating of all land records within the district.

sections.title: Law and Order.
sections.content_md: Maintaining law and order throughout the district, often in coordination with the police department.

sections.title: Supervision and execution of all plans of the Union and State governments.
sections.content_md: Overseeing the supervision and execution of all developmental plans and schemes launched by the Union and State governments.

sections.title: Provision of civic amenities and execution of public works.
sections.content_md: Ensuring the provision of civic amenities to the public and overseeing the execution of public works projects.

sections.title: Implementation of policies and programmes in respect of Panchayati Raj institutions.
sections.content_md: The Deputy Commissioner is also represented on the Zila Parishad and influences and implements policies and programmes related to Panchayati Raj institutions.

sections.title: Supersession, dissolution, holding of election, etc., in respect of Panchayati Raj institutions.
sections.content_md: Exercising administrative control over Panchayati Raj institutions, which includes actions like their supersession or dissolution, and conducting elections.
